St. Agnes' Eve — Ah, bitter chill it was!</br>The owl, for all his feathers, was a-cold;</br>The hare limp'd trembling through the frozen grass,</br>And silent was the flock in woolly fold:</br>Numb were the Beadsman's fingers, while he told</br>His rosary, and while his frosted breath,</br>Like pious incense from a censer old,</br>Seem'd taking flight for heaven, without a death,</br>Past the sweet Virgin's picture, while his prayer he saith.

His prayer he saith, this patient, holy man;</br>Then takes his lamp, and riseth from his knees,</br>And back returneth, meagre, barefoot, wan,</br>Along the chapel aisle by slow degrees:</br>The sculptur'd dead, on each side, seem to freeze,</br>Emprison'd in black, purgatorial rails:</br>Knights, ladies, praying in dumb orat'ries,</br>He passeth by; and his weak spirit fails</br>To think how they may ache in icy hoods and mails.

Northward he turneth through a little door,</br>And scarce three steps, ere Music's golden tongue</br>Flatter'd to tears this aged man and poor;</br>But no — already had his deathbell rung;</br>The joys of all his life were said and sung:</br>His was harsh penance on St. Agnes' Eve:</br>Another way he went, and soon among</br>Rough ashes sat he for his soul's reprieve,</br>And all night kept awake, for sinners' sake to grieve.

That ancient Beadsman heard the prelude soft;</br>And so it chanc'd, for many a door was wide,</br>From hurry to and fro.  Soon, up aloft,</br>The silver, snarling trumpets 'gan to chide:</br>The level chambers, ready with their pride,</br>Were glowing to receive a thousand guests:</br>The carved angels, ever eager-eyed,</br>Star'd, where upon their heads the cornice rests,</br>With hair blown back, and wings put cross-wise on their breasts.

At length burst in the argent revelry,</br>With plume, tiara, and all rich array,</br>Numerous as shadows haunting fairily</br>The brain, new stuff'd, in youth, with triumphs gay</br>Of old romance.  These let us wish away,</br>And turn, sole-thoughted, to one Lady there,</br>Whose heart had brooded, all that wintry day,</br>On love, and wing'd St. Agnes' saintly care,</br>As she had heard old dames full many times declare.

They told her how, upon St. Agnes' Eve,</br>Young virgins might have visions of delight,</br>And soft adorings from their loves receive</br>Upon the honey'd middle of the night,</br>If ceremonies due they did aright;</br>As, supperless to bed they must retire,</br>And couch supine their beauties, lily white;</br>Nor look behind, nor sideways, but require</br>Of Heaven with upward eyes for all that they desire.

Full of this whim was thoughtful Madeline:</br>The music, yearning like a God in pain,</br>She scarcely heard:  her maiden eyes divine,</br>Fix'd on the floor, saw many a sweeping train</br>Pass by — she heeded not at all:  in vain</br>Came many a tiptoe, amorous cavalier,</br>And back retir'd; not cool'd by high disdain,</br>But she saw not:  her heart was otherwhere:</br>She sigh'd for Agnes' dreams, the sweetest of the year.

She danc'd along with vague, regardless eyes,</br>Anxious her lips, her breathing quick and short:</br>The hallow'd hour was near at hand:  she sighs</br>Amid the timbrels, and the throng'd resort</br>Of whisperers in anger, or in sport;</br>'Mid looks of love, defiance, hate, and scorn,</br>Hoodwink'd with faery fancy; all amort,</br>Save to St. Agnes and her lambs unshorn,</br>And all the bliss to be before to-morrow morn.

So, purposing each moment to retire,</br>She linger'd still.  Meantime, across the moors,</br>Had come young Porphyro, with heart on fire</br>For Madeline.  Beside the portal doors,</br>Buttress'd from moonlight, stands he, and implores</br>All saints to give him sight of Madeline,</br>But for one moment in the tedious hours,</br>That he might gaze and worship all unseen;</br>Perchance speak, kneel, touch, kiss — in sooth such things have been.

He ventures in:  let no buzz'd whisper tell:</br>All eyes be muffled, or a hundred swords</br>Will storm his heart, Love's fev'rous citadel:</br>For him, those chambers held barbarian hordes,</br>Hyena foemen, and hot-blooded lords,</br>Whose very dogs would execrations howl</br>Against his lineage:  not one breast affords</br>Him any mercy, in that mansion foul,</br>Save one old beldame, weak in body and in soul.

Ah, happy chance!  the aged creature came,</br>Shuffling along with ivory-headed wand,</br>To where he stood, hid from the torch's flame,</br>Behind a broad hall-pillar, far beyond</br>The sound of merriment and chorus bland:</br>He startled her; but soon she knew his face,</br>And grasp'd his fingers in her palsied hand,</br>Saying, "Mercy, Porphyro!  hie thee from this place;</br>They are all here to-night, the whole blood-thirsty race!

"Get hence!  get hence!  there's dwarfish Hildebrand;</br>He had a fever late, and in the fit</br>He cursed thee and thine, both house and land:</br>Then there's that old Lord Maurice, not a whit</br>More tame for his gray hairs — Alas me!  flit!</br>Flit like a ghost away." — "Ah, Gossip dear,</br>We're safe enough; here in this arm-chair sit,</br>And tell me how" — "Good Saints!  not here, not here;</br>Follow me, child, or else these stones will be thy bier."

He follow'd through a lowly arched way,</br>Brushing the cobwebs with his lofty plume,</br>And as she mutter'd "Well-a — well-a-day!"</br>He found him in a little moonlight room,</br>Pale, lattic'd, chill, and silent as a tomb.</br>"Now tell me where is Madeline," said he,</br>"O tell me, Angela, by the holy loom</br>Which none but secret sisterhood may see,</br>When they St. Agnes' wool are weaving piously."

"St. Agnes!  Ah!  it is St. Agnes' Eve—</br>Yet men will murder upon holy days:</br>Thou must hold water in a witch's sieve,</br>And be liege-lord of all the Elves and Fays,</br>To venture so:  it fills me with amaze</br>To see thee, Porphyro! — St. Agnes' Eve!</br>God's help!  my lady fair the conjuror plays</br>This very night:  good angels her deceive!</br>But let me laugh awhile, I've mickle time to grieve."

Feebly she laugheth in the languid moon,</br>While Porphyro upon her face doth look,</br>Like puzzled urchin on an aged crone</br>Who keepeth clos'd a wond'rous riddle-book,</br>As spectacled she sits in chimney nook.</br>But soon his eyes grew brilliant, when she told</br>His lady's purpose; and he scarce could brook</br>Tears, at the thought of those enchantments cold,</br>And Madeline asleep in lap of legends old.

Sudden a thought came like a full-blown rose,</br>Flushing his brow, and in his pained heart</br>Made purple riot:  then doth he propose</br>A stratagem, that makes the beldame start:</br>"A cruel man and impious thou art:</br>Sweet lady, let her pray, and sleep, and dream</br>Alone with her good angels, far apart</br>From wicked men like thee.  Go, go! — I deem</br>Thou canst not surely be the same that thou didst seem."

"I will not harm her, by all saints I swear,"</br>Quoth Porphyro:  "O may I ne'er find grace</br>When my weak voice shall whisper its last prayer,</br>If one of her soft ringlets I displace,</br>Or look with ruffian passion in her face:</br>Good Angela, believe me by these tears;</br>Or I will, even in a moment's space,</br>Awake, with horrid shout, my foemen's ears,</br>And beard them, though they be more fang'd than wolves and bears."

"Ah!  why wilt thou affright a feeble soul?</br>A poor, weak, palsy-stricken, churchyard thing,</br>Whose passing-bell may ere the midnight toll;</br>Whose prayers for thee, each morn and evening,</br>Were never miss'd." — Thus plaining, doth she bring</br>A gentler speech from burning Porphyro;</br>So woful, and of such deep sorrowing,</br>That Angela gives promise she will do</br>Whatever he shall wish, betide her weal or woe.

Which was, to lead him, in close secrecy,</br>Even to Madeline's chamber, and there hide</br>Him in a closet, of such privacy</br>That he might see her beauty unespied,</br>And win perhaps that night a peerless bride,</br>While legion'd fairies pac'd the coverlet,</br>And pale enchantment held her sleepy-eyed.</br>Never on such a night have lovers met,</br>Since Merlin paid his Demon all the monstrous debt.

"It shall be as thou wishest," said the Dame:</br>"All cates and dainties shall be stored there</br>Quickly on this feast-night:  by the tambour frame</br>Her own lute thou wilt see:  no time to spare,</br>For I am slow and feeble, and scarce dare</br>On such a catering trust my dizzy head.</br>Wait here, my child, with patience; kneel in prayer</br>The while:  Ah!  thou must needs the lady wed,</br>Or may I never leave my grave among the dead."

So saying, she hobbled off with busy fear.</br>The lover's endless minutes slowly pass'd;</br>The dame return'd, and whisper'd in his ear</br>To follow her; with aged eyes aghast</br>From fright of dim espial.  Safe at last,</br>Through many a dusky gallery, they gain</br>The maiden's chamber, silken, hush'd, and chaste;</br>Where Porphyro took covert, pleas'd amain.</br>His poor guide hurried back with agues in her brain.

Her falt'ring hand upon the balustrade,</br>Old Angela was feeling for the stair,</br>When Madeline, St. Agnes' charmed maid,</br>Rose, like a mission'd spirit, unaware:</br>With silver taper's light, and pious care,</br>She turn'd, and down the aged gossip led</br>To a safe level matting.  Now prepare,</br>Young Porphyro, for gazing on that bed;</br>She comes, she comes again, like ring-dove fray'd and fled.

Out went the taper as she hurried in;</br>Its little smoke, in pallid moonshine, died:</br>She clos'd the door, she panted, all akin</br>To spirits of the air, and visions wide:</br>No uttered syllable, or, woe betide!</br>But to her heart, her heart was voluble,</br>Paining with eloquence her balmy side;</br>As though a tongueless nightingale should swell</br>Her throat in vain, and die, heart-stifled, in her dell.

A casement high and triple-arch'd there was,</br>All garlanded with carven imag'ries</br>Of fruits, and flowers, and bunches of knot-grass,</br>And diamonded with panes of quaint device,</br>Innumerable of stains and splendid dyes,</br>As are the tiger-moth's deep-damask'd wings;</br>And in the midst, 'mong thousand heraldries,</br>And twilight saints, and dim emblazonings,</br>A shielded scutcheon blush'd with blood of queens and kings.

Full on this casement shone the wintry moon,</br>And threw warm gules on Madeline's fair breast,</br>As down she knelt for heaven's grace and boon;</br>Rose-bloom fell on her hands, together prest,</br>And on her silver cross soft amethyst,</br>And on her hair a glory, like a saint:</br>She seem'd a splendid angel, newly drest,</br>Save wings, for heaven: — Porphyro grew faint:</br>She knelt, so pure a thing, so free from mortal taint.

Anon his heart revives:  her vespers done,</br>Of all its wreathed pearls her hair she frees;</br>Unclasps her warmed jewels one by one;</br>Loosens her fragrant boddice; by degrees</br>Her rich attire creeps rustling to her knees:</br>Half-hidden, like a mermaid in sea-weed,</br>Pensive awhile she dreams awake, and sees,</br>In fancy, fair St. Agnes in her bed,</br>But dares not look behind, or all the charm is fled.

Soon, trembling in her soft and chilly nest,</br>In sort of wakeful swoon, perplex'd she lay,</br>Until the poppied warmth of sleep oppress'd</br>Her soothed limbs, and soul fatigued away;</br>Flown, like a thought, until the morrow-day;</br>Blissfully haven'd both from joy and pain;</br>Clasp'd like a missal where swart Paynims pray;</br>Blinded alike from sunshine and from rain,</br>As though a rose should shut, and be a bud again.

Stol'n to this paradise, and so entranced,</br>Porphyro gazed upon her empty dress,</br>And listen'd to her breathing, if it chanced</br>To wake into a slumberous tenderness;</br>Which when he heard, that minute did he bless,</br>And breath'd himself:  then from the closet crept,</br>Noiseless as fear in a wide wilderness,</br>And over the hush'd carpet, silent, stept,</br>And 'tween the curtains peep'd, where, lo! — how fast she slept.

Then by the bed-side, where the faded moon</br>Made a dim, silver twilight, soft he set</br>A table, and, half anguish'd, threw thereon</br>A cloth of woven crimson, gold, and jet:—</br>O for some drowsy Morphean amulet!</br>The boisterous, midnight, festive clarion,</br>The kettle-drum, and far-heard clarionet,</br>Affray his ears, though but in dying tone:—</br>The hall door shuts again, and all the noise is gone.

And still she slept an azure-lidded sleep,</br>In blanched linen, smooth, and lavender'd,</br>While he from forth the closet brought a heap</br>Of candied apple, quince, and plum, and gourd;</br>With jellies soother than the creamy curd,</br>And lucent syrops, tinct with cinnamon;</br>Manna and dates, in argosy transferr'd</br>From Fez; and spiced dainties, every one,</br>From silken Samarcand to cedar'd Lebanon.

These delicates he heap'd with glowing hand</br>On golden dishes and in baskets bright</br>Of wreathed silver:  sumptuous they stand</br>In the retired quiet of the night,</br>Filling the chilly room with perfume light.—</br>"And now, my love, my seraph fair, awake!</br>Thou art my heaven, and I thine eremite:</br>Open thine eyes, for meek St. Agnes' sake,</br>Or I shall drowse beside thee, so my soul doth ache."

Thus whispering, his warm, unnerved arm</br>Sank in her pillow.  Shaded was her dream</br>By the dusk curtains: — 'twas a midnight charm</br>Impossible to melt as iced stream:</br>The lustrous salvers in the moonlight gleam;</br>Broad golden fringe upon the carpet lies:</br>It seem'd he never, never could redeem</br>From such a stedfast spell his lady's eyes;</br>So mus'd awhile, entoil'd in woofed phantasies.

Awakening up, he took her hollow lute,—</br>Tumultuous, — and, in chords that tenderest be,</br>He play'd an ancient ditty, long since mute,</br>In Provence call'd, "La belle dame sans mercy:"</br>Close to her ear touching the melody;—</br>Wherewith disturb'd, she utter'd a soft moan:</br>He ceased — she panted quick — and suddenly</br>Her blue affrayed eyes wide open shone:</br>Upon his knees he sank, pale as smooth-sculptured stone.

Her eyes were open, but she still beheld,</br>Now wide awake, the vision of her sleep:</br>There was a painful change, that nigh expell'd</br>The blisses of her dream so pure and deep</br>At which fair Madeline began to weep,</br>And moan forth witless words with many a sigh;</br>While still her gaze on Porphyro would keep;</br>Who knelt, with joined hands and piteous eye,</br>Fearing to move or speak, she look'd so dreamingly.

"Ah, Porphyro!"  said she, "but even now</br>Thy voice was at sweet tremble in mine ear,</br>Made tuneable with every sweetest vow;</br>And those sad eyes were spiritual and clear:</br>How chang'd thou art!  how pallid, chill, and drear!</br>Give me that voice again, my Porphyro,</br>Those looks immortal, those complainings dear!</br>Oh leave me not in this eternal woe,</br>For if thou diest, my Love, I know not where to go."

Beyond a mortal man impassion'd far</br>At these voluptuous accents, he arose,</br>Ethereal, flush'd, and like a throbbing star</br>Seen mid the sapphire heaven's deep repose;</br>Into her dream he melted, as the rose</br>Blendeth its odour with the violet,—</br>Solution sweet:  meantime the frost-wind blows</br>Like Love's alarum pattering the sharp sleet</br>Against the window-panes; St. Agnes' moon hath set.

'Tis dark:  quick pattereth the flaw-blown sleet:</br>"This is no dream, my bride, my Madeline!"</br>'Tis dark:  the iced gusts still rave and beat:</br>No dream, alas!  alas!  and woe is mine!</br>"Porphyro will leave me here to fade and pine.—</br>Cruel!  what traitor could thee hither bring?</br>I curse not, for my heart is lost in thine,</br>Though thou forsakest a deceived thing;—</br>A dove forlorn and lost with sick unpruned wing."

"My Madeline!  sweet dreamer!  lovely bride!</br>Say, may I be for aye thy vassal blest?</br>Thy beauty's shield, heart-shap'd and vermeil dyed?</br>Ah, silver shrine, here will I take my rest</br>After so many hours of toil and quest,</br>A famish'd pilgrim, — saved by miracle.</br>Though I have found, I will not rob thy nest</br>Saving of thy sweet self; if thou think'st well</br>To trust, fair Madeline, to no rude infidel."

"Hark!  'tis an elfin-storm from faery land,</br>Of haggard seeming, but a boon indeed:</br>Arise — arise!  the morning is at hand;—</br>The bloated wassaillers will never heed:—</br>Let us away, my love, with happy speed;</br>There are no ears to hear, or eyes to see,—</br>Drown'd all in Rhenish and the sleepy mead:</br>Awake!  arise!  my love, and fearless be,</br>For o'er the southern moors I have a home for thee."

She hurried at his words, beset with fears,</br>For there were sleeping dragons all around,</br>At glaring watch, perhaps, with ready spears—</br>Down the wide stairs a darkling way they found.—</br>In all the house was heard no human sound.</br>A chain-droop'd lamp was flickering by each door;</br>The arras, rich with horseman, hawk, and hound,</br>Flutter'd in the besieging wind's uproar;</br>And the long carpets rose along the gusty floor.

They glide, like phantoms, into the wide hall;</br>Like phantoms, to the iron porch, they glide;</br>Where lay the Porter, in uneasy sprawl,</br>With a huge empty flaggon by his side:</br>The wakeful bloodhound rose, and shook his hide,</br>But his sagacious eye an inmate owns:</br>By one, and one, the bolts full easy slide:—</br>The chains lie silent on the footworn stones;—</br>The key turns, and the door upon its hinges groans.

And they are gone:  ay, ages long ago</br>These lovers fled away into the storm.</br>That night the Baron dreamt of many a woe,</br>And all his warrior-guests, with shade and form</br>Of witch, and demon, and large coffin-worm,</br>Were long be-nightmar'd.  Angela the old</br>Died palsy-twitch'd, with meagre face deform;</br>The Beadsman, after thousand aves told,</br>For aye unsought for slept among his ashes cold.</br>
